description:
General principles of biology that have been established by studies of microbes, animals, and plants and the viruses of these organisms will be covered. Emphasis will be on the basic chemistry of life, cell biology, molecular biology, and genetics. The study of developmental pathways and evolutionary trends in life cycles will be explored using plants as model organisms. 

Biology Majors and Pre-Medical students should take either BIOL 101 or 121. BIOL 101 is the companion course to BIOL 102, may be taken before or after BIOL 102. 

Lab fee $150.
name: INTRO BIOLOGY A

values.comments:
Topics covered include: viruses, bacteria, protozoa and plants, and the general
principles of biology that have been established by studies of these organisms. Emphasis
is on cell and molecular biology, genetics, development, diversity of adaptations and
evolution.
Students described the material as “dull,” but “useful.” Many students noted that
the course relied heavily on memorization. Many students also noted that the range of
material covered was quite extensive.
Student described Professor Daldal as “engaging” and noted that he really made
students “care about what we were learning.” Some students complained that due to his
accent, however, his lectures were sometimes difficult to understand. However, many
students credited him with being able to present difficult and extensive material in a
comprehensive way.
The class was considered very “difficult” and the workload extensive, but a
“necessary evil if you’re pre-med.” One student said that the assigned reading can be
“mountainous and overwhelming.”

This class is an introduction to the general principles of biology through the study
of microbes, animals, plants and viruses. It emphasizes the basic chemistry of life, cell
biology, molecular biology, and genetics. The study of developmental pathways and
evolutionary trends in life cycles are explored using plants as model organisms.
Students felt like there was a lot of material covered in this course; some felt it
was too much for an introductory course. Many agreed that it was easy to fall behind on
the material, as there was so much reading. Overall, students felt that the course was
largely based on memorization.
Students agreed that Dr. Casper was enthusiastic and “very passionate”, but her
powerpoints and lectures tended to be disorganized.
This course is useful for students interested in medicine or the sciences. It fulfills
the Living World Sector; BIOL 102 is a companion course. Many noted that the course
was competitive and the curve was steep; some students also felt that the tests weren’t
always clearly written. However, many noted that if you stay on top of coursework, you
will be able to achieve an above average grade.

General principles of biology that have been established by studies of microbes,
animals, plants and the viruses of these organisms are covered. Emphasis is placed on the
basic chemistry of life, cell biology, molecular biology, and genetics. The study of
developmental pathways and evolutionary trends in life cycles is explored using plants as
model organisms.
Students described this class as “rather boring… though extremely informative.”
Students also mentioned that they learned a lot from the course, stating that it discusses a
“vast amount” of information. That being said, some students complained that the course
did not revolve around an actual comprehension of the material on a conceptual level,
and instead “memorization [was] the key to success” in the class.
Students overwhelmingly commended Professor Sanders for his “solid sense of
humor.” He was described as “an excellent professor” who “cares about his students and
wants them to understand the material.” However, some students complained about his
lack of organization in lecture, and some reported that they “didn’t learn much in class
that [they] couldn’t learn from reading through the slides online.”
This course requires a lot of work, with several students saying it “greatly subjects
itself to individual studying and effort to master it.” Additionally, tests were not
necessarily a “fair reflection of what… [was] learned in class and studied outside.” Some
students complained that test questions were “poorly or vaguely worded.”
